content.webTitle: What you need to teach at LSE? A role in Maleficent | Catherine Bennett

fields.headline: What do you need to teach at LSE? A role in Maleficent
fields.bodyText: Though it may take a while to establish her long-term contribution to the reputational recovery of the LSE, following its embrace of the Gaddafis , the awarding of a professorship to the actor and humanitarian envoy Angelina Jolie has already helped distract from that university’s ranking in the latest league table. So much so that the makers of these lists may want to consider adding a celebrity variable to valuations such as student satisfaction and job prospects. What percentage of the university’s teaching staff has appeared in a top-grossing film, such as Professor Jolie Pitt’s Maleficent? Rates high for gowns? How many undergraduates are forced to endure three years of toil without meeting someone who has been up – at least – for a Bafta? Recalculated on that basis, the LSE comes top of all the universities in the world, with Oxford in second place, the credit for that going entirely to one college, Lady Margaret Hall. It recently awarded visiting fellowships to, among others, Emma Watson, Benedict Cumberbatch and Neil Tennant, of the Pet Shop Boys, promising “fascinating interactions”. Rewardingly, for those who appointed her to a teaching post on the LSE’s forthcoming MSc in women, peace and security, excitement about Ms Jolie Pitt’s arrival also added lustre to her partner scholar, Professor William Hague’s simultaneous appointment – one which might otherwise have dismayed any applicants aware of the protracted period that preceded his interest in women, peace and security. Indeed, all the time he was foreign secretary, Hague’s concern for women never impaired relations with, for example, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and other countries responsible for their brutal subjugation. Closer to home, there is nothing on record that suggests anything other than complete contentment, on Professor Hague’s part, with a Westminster system that consistently pushes women politicians to the margins. In 2013, a year after he began collaborating with Professor Jolie Pitt, he could be found mouthing “stupid woman” at a fellow parliamentarian. But here he is ornamenting the LSE’s Gender Institute, repurposed and redeemed by the same Jolie Pitt effect that has, for the LSE, banished all thoughts of Saif Gaddafi, and his PhD. I won’t be the only graduate who rushed to see if I might be eligible, academically and financially, to sit at the new professors’ feet. The course does not begin until autumn 2016, when the Institute is likely to want something along the lines in place for its existing MSc in gender, development and globalisation: a 2:1, and at least £12,000. Core courses will include those Professor Hague specialities “gender and militarisation”, “gender and human rights” and, of course, “stupid women, peace and security”. All students will write a dissertation. It’s tempting. Then again, if Professor Jolie Pitt acquired her academic title without a single formal academic qualification, and her fellow amateur’s gender insights do not promise to exceed the average gnat’s, is it worth investing one year and a lot of money in pointless study? The LSE must have been aware that, in issuing these celebrity professorships, as opposed to guest speaker invitations, it completely trashes, as it attempts to burnish, its academic hierarchy. Maybe applicants should apply, instead, to LMH, where a majority of the celebrity fellows have GCSEs – not that these attributes were mentioned in a glowing, Hello! magazine report , celebrating the moment Oxbridge finally caught up. “It comes as no surprise,” reported the magazine’s higher education correspondent, “that Emma and Benedict topped the final list.” True, most of the MSc’s teaching will be by qualified LSE staff, whose careers followed the conventional pattern of graduation, research, publication. To be fair, Professor Hague has also published, notably his William Pitt the Younger. Perhaps with less impact, Professor Jolie Pitt published, in 2003, Notes From My Travels: Visits with Refugees in Africa, Cambodia, Pakistan, and Ecuador. There is no doubting, from these jottings, Professor Jolie Pitt’s deep concern for refugees, her horror over their suffering, and her commitment to their cause. Publicising their plight, she showed herself an exemplary ambassador for the UNHCR. Graduate applicants for the LSE’s MSc will judge for themselves, however, how far her insights – designed to rouse a torpid public – promise to advance their own knowledge. “I honestly believe,” she begins, “that if we were all aware, we would all be compelled to act.” Extensive detail follows about people who have moved her, punctuated by helpless asides. “I don’t know what to do,” Jolie Pitt says. “I don’t know what I am feeling.” “I don’t know how many more stories I can hear.” “I don’t know what to write or what I feel.” She concludes: “Refugees are families and individuals just like us but they don’t have the freedom we have. Their human rights have been violated.” At least we can be fairly confident no dictator’s son will be asking for help with his PhD. As effective as Jolie Pitt’s many visits have been, most recently raising awareness about sexual violence in conflict, , it does not seem impossible that the full-time workers who choreographed her fact-finding missions, and academics researching in this field, might have yet more to share with postgraduates whose interests go beyond motivational speeches. “Strength lies in being unafraid,” Jolie Pitt told the BBC on World on the Move day. Helpfully for the LSE, any suggestion that the film star’s promotion is an insult to the better qualified, but obscure, elicits accusations of snobbishness and sexism – regardless of the fact that Hague’s, too, is a celebrity appointment, and one, moreover, farcically misplaced in a gender institute. The positions, it is emphasised , are of the special, “visiting professors in practice” variety. So it might be best if applicants discover before, rather than after they’ve signed up, that the 2014 summit which constitutes the main, Hague-Jolie claim to in-practice expertise, cost £5.2m: five times more, the Observer reported, than the entire confirmed budget the UK dedicated to tackling rape in war zones the following year. Hague has since stepped down from the government project. Marcy Hersh, of the Women’s Refugee Commission, told the Observer: “For an initiative that used such lofty language, I struggle to see what the initiative has tangibly created, other than recognition, acknowledgment and sympathy for the issue.” To be fair, that was before the LSE created the professorships. Of course, if students are as dazzled by star quality as these appointments suggest, they will be as relaxed about a wasteful summit as they are about conspicuous inexperience. Irrespective of their verdict, an enthusiastic press response has already acclaimed the LSE’s opening raid on the sidebar of shame as a creditable advance in the marketisation of higher education. So the arrival of the LSE’s Tomb Raider professorship, along with the reporting of Oxford fellowships in Hello! magazine, should be a reminder to more squeamish competitors, that, if they don’t get moving, all the best celebrities will be snapped up. Strength lies in being unafraid. Madonna is, I understand, available. Unless, as a mature celebrity and performer, the singer thinks a Russell Group professorship somewhat beneath her dignity.
